#Text=Choose a Fund Manager
#Text=By choosing the right fund to invest your money in , you can have a team of professionals picking stocks , managing your money and executing trades .

#Text=Large funds can afford to have a separate person focusing on picking stocks , allocating the assets of the fund into different areas ( stocks , bonds , cash , etc ) and managing the most efficient tax position .
#Text=Large funds may also re-invest some of their money into other funds in the pursuit of lower risk and higher gains .
#Text=The great thing about mutual funds is that you share the cost of these services with thousands of other investors in the same fund .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Research the fund manager 's track record .
#Text=Not every fund performs well .
#Text=Just because a fund has performed well in the past does n’t necessarily tell you how the fund will perform in the future .
#Text=In picking a fund , it helps to research the fund ’s key personnel , their experience and accomplishments , the fees they charge , and their investment style .
#Text=Managing other people ’s money requires experience , maturity and a strong sense of responsibility .
#Text=Check a fund manager ’s track record .
#Text=How well did they do at the last fund they managed ?
#Text=While veteran managers ca n't guarantee better performance than a fresh face , there is a lot to be said for experience in the markets .
#Text=Having a long view of your manager ’s history will help you to see how they performed in both bull ( strong ) and bear ( weak ) markets .
#Text=A consistent performer in both good and bad times is more likely to bring you peace of mind with your investments .
#Text=How does a manager 's track record compare to that of his/her peers ?
#Text=Be careful with comparisons .
#Text=Different managers employ different investing styles .
#Text=Some choose growth stocks , ones they expect to grow in value without paying much in dividends .
#Text=Others may look for income from dividends .
#Text=Still others may choose stocks they believe the market has undervalued .
#Text=Add “ Alpha ” :
#Text=An important measure of a fund manager ’s value is the “ alpha ” that they can add .
#Text=“ Alpha ” is the measure of how much more the manager adds to the value of your investment than if you had simply invested in an index fund .
#Text=An index fund attempts to mirror the market by investing in every company ( or a representative sampling of companies ) listed in a particular index .
#Text=Such a list may reflect a particular industry , economic sector , geographic region , company size , or investing style .
#Text=You can discover a fund 's " alpha " measurement by researching the fund online at Morningstar.com or various other fund-analysis services .
#Text=Compare with index funds .
#Text=Generally index funds charge lower fees , because they face lower research-and-analysis expenses .
#Text=They may be expected to do as well as the relevant market in general .
#Text=If , on the other hand , you choose to pay the higher fees associated with a managed fund , be sure that the fund manager is not merely following some index .
#Text=Video
#Text=Tips
#Text=In regulated financial markets like Europe , UK and Australia , governing bodies publish regular performance figures of the various funds on offer .
#Text=These bodies will have information about the key personnel running a fund and may also attempt to define their specific styles .
#Text=In the United States there are a number of online sources of such information , notably Morningstar .
